Guangzhou Institute of Energy Conversion, Chinese Academy of Sciences Guangzhou Guangdong 510640 China Production of γ-valerolactone (GVL) from biomass-derived platform levulinic acid (LA) via catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) over renewable lignosulfonate-derived catalyst is reported herein. Lignosulfonate-derived catalysts were prepared by assembled Zr-metals with sodium lignosulfonate (LigS) derived from the industry paper waste. The resulting Zr-LigS catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance in 92.5% GVL yield under mild conditions. With the combination of detail catalyst characterizations, catalytic performance of the Zr-LigS catalyst, in-situ ATR-FTIR and poisoning experiments, the hydrothermal treatment of Zr4+ and LigS resulted in the formation of basic sites, which contributed significantly to the CTH reaction. Kinetic experiments demonstrated that the activation energy was as low as 41.9 kJ/mol. Furthermore, isotopic labeling experiments suggested that the β-H in isopropanol is transferred to the CO bond of LA by the formation of six-membered intermediates on the basic sites, which is the rate-determining step. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Catalytic transfer hydrogenation Biomass Renewable catalyst Biofuels Heterogeneous catalysts 1 Introduction Utilization of biomass (hemicellulose, cellulose, lignin and their derived platform chemicals), the only plentiful source of non-food renewable resource, is a sustainable method to supply renewable bio-fuels and high value-added chemicals [1–3]. Recently, catalytic conversion of renewable biomass-derived platform chemicals (furfural, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural, glycerol, levulinic acid (LA) and glycerol) has gained significant attentions [4–8]. LA is considered as the most promising biomass derived platform, which was hailed as one of the top ten valuable platform compound by the United States Department of Energy (DOE) [9]. LA could be further converted into high value derivatives such as γ-valerolactone (GVL) [10], valerate ester[11], levulinic ester[12], 2-methyltetrahydrofuran [13] and n-alkanes [14]. Among these high value derivatives, GVL can be used as fuel additive for gasoline or green solvent in the valorization of biomass [15,16]. Besides, GVL could be transformed to butenes via decarboxylation and ring opening reactions, and the product butenes could be further upgraded to lubrication oil or liquid fuels [17]. Furthermore, GVL can be converted to high value products valerate ester through ring opening, hydrogenation and esterification [18]. The catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of biomass derived aldehydes to the corresponding alcohols is a promising approach to substitute dangerous gaseous H2 by employing safe and abundant alcohol or acid as hydrogen donor [19,20]. Amphoteric metal catalysts such as Fe [21], Zr[22,23], Co[24], Cu[25], Hf [26] and Al[27] were reported as efficient catalysts for the CTH of bio-derived aldehydes. Among those metal catalysts, Zr-base catalysts, such as Zr-BEA[28,29], ZrO(OH)2 [38], ZrO2 [30], modified ZrH catalyst [31,32], Zr metal organic frameworks [33–36] and ZrFeOx [37] were developed for the CTH reaction in alcohols. Recently, Zr organic-inorganic hybrid materials, assembled various of organic ligand with Zr4+ [38–43], was demonstrated to be efficient catalysts for the CTH reactions. However, the complex preparation process, toxic organic solvent (N, N-dimethylformamide) and the expensive organic ligands limit its large-scale implementation. Therefore, it is desirable to develop an efficient, cheap, green and renewable catalyst. Lignosulfonate (LigS) was the main by-product in the paper and pulp industry, which was directly combusted as fuel [44]. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop the industrial lignin in biorefinery and pulping industry. LigS is a promising materials of value-added metal-biopolymer hybrid material due to the plentiful active functional groups (sulfonic group, alcohol and phenolic hydroxyl) [45]. Since the CTH of LA is a meaningful reaction, the conversion pathway was studied by ex-situ gas chromatograph (GC) and the conversion intermediates were detected in vapor phase. However, most of reactions were performed in the presence of solvents, i.e., alcohols in this study not only worked as solvent, but also as a hydrogen donor, which posed great challenges in exploring structure-activity relationships resulting in the poor understand in solvent effect because most of the characterizations were carried under vacuum or vapor phase. The chemical reactions at the solid-liquid interface were affected by interactions that can stabilize or destabilize adsorbates, intermediates, and transition states, transforming the reaction coordinate diagram, and resulting in modified rate and selectivity [3]. Thus, it is eager to characterize catalyst under identical conditions i.e., in the presence of solvent. Xu used in-situ Attenuated Total Reflection (ATR)-FTIR based spectroscopic techniques to detect the pyridine adsorbed on NaY zeolite in liquid water [37]. Besides, they employed in-situ ATR-FTIR to quantitatively measure adsorption isotherms, which provided a tool to understand the solvent effects on adsorption and protonation in catalysts [38]. In this work, we prepared renewable Zr-LigS catalyst by renewable industry paper waste LigS. The resulting Zr-LigS catalyst was employed to catalyze the CTH of LA. Extensive characterizations were carried to demonstrate the acid-base properties of active sites on catalyst surface. In-situ ATR-FTIR and poisoning experiments were employed to study the effect of in-situ generated (Brønsted acid sites) BAS on the activity in liquid phase. Kinetic experiments were performed to investigate the relationship between active site and their catalytic performance. Deuterium isotope labeled experiments were conducted to further explore the mechanism of CTH reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Sodium ligninsulfonate, ZrCl4, HfCl4, CuCl2·2H2O, FeCl3·6H2O, ZnCl2·6H2O, LA, ZrO2, 1-propanol (99.9%), 2-propanol (IPA, 99.9%), ethanol (99.9%), 1-butanol (99.9%), 2-butanol (99.8%), tert-butanol (99.9%), 3-pentanol (99.9%), sulfuric acid (98%) and methanol (99%) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd., 2-propanol-d 8 were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. All chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts Typically, 5 g ZrCl4 and 5 g sodium ligninsulfonate were dissolved into 15 mL and 50 mL deionized water, respectively. Then ultrasound for 10 min to obtain evenly dispersed solution. The two solutions were mixed and 1 mL sulfuric acid (98%) was added to the solution, then stirred for 30 min at room temperature. Then the mixture was transferred to a autoclave (Anhui Kemi Machinery Technology Co., Ltd., Anhui, China; MS100-P5-T4-HC1-SV) and the autoclave was heated to 120 °C for 12 h. After that, the catalyst precursor was washed by deionized water for 15 times and then washed by ethanol for 3 times to obtain neutral filtrate. The obtained sample was dried at 60 °C for 12 h to obtained Zr-LigS (1) catalyst. We also prepared other Zr-LigS (1) following the same procedure as Zr-LigS (1) by changing the mass ratio of commerical ZrCl4 and sodium ligninsulfonate from 0.5 to 2. These catalysts are designated as Zr-LigS (0.5), Zr-LigS (1.5) and Zr-LigS (2). For comparison, the Hf-LigS, Fe-LigS, Zn-LigS and Al-LigS were prepared under the same procedure. Conventional organic framework UIO-66 was prepared based on the previous work [46]. 2.3 Products analysis The products were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) equipped with FID detector. The oven temperature was increased to 60 °C for 2 min, and then increased to 200 °C with 10 °C/min and hold for 10 min. Helium was the carrier gas with split ratio of 5:1. A trapezoidal ZnSe (45° cut) ATR crystal provides six total internal reflections. Before depositing catalyst on the ZnSe crystal, the mirror between the ATR cell and the detector was adjusted to maintain a constant interferogram intensity of 5.0 (arbitrary units on Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer). The catalyst layer is directly deposited on the top side of the ATR crystal by evaporation of the solvent from a catalyst slurry. The seal between the ZnSe crystal and the top plate is achieved by pressing an O-ring into a groove on the bottom surface of the top plate. The internal dimensions of the cell are 1.75 in. length × 0.5 in. width × 20 µm thickness for a total volume of 1.1 × 10−2 cm3. A piece of quartz microfiber filter paper (2.7 µm pore size, Whatman Inc.) is placed between the catalyst layer and the top plate to prevent catalyst powder from being washed out by flowing solvent. No loss of catalyst was observed in any experiments reported in this work with up to 24 h of continuous flow of solvents. Solvents with dissolved substrate, e.g., LA, pyridine, are introduced to the catalyst layer via an HPLC pump (Waters 515) at a rate ranging from 0.1 mL/min. The ATR-FTIR spectroscopy samples both the bulk liquid phase and the liquid-solid interface within the penetration depth of the evanescent wave from the top of the ZnSe crystal. Thus, spectra contain signals from both bulk and adsorbed species. Spectroscopic features of the probe molecule in the bulk solution, e.g., LA, are removed by running an identical experiment devoid of catalyst and performing a subtraction. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature and the mixtures were centrifuged and the used catalysts were collected for the recycling experiments. 2.7 Isotopic labelled experiments For isotopic kinetic study of CTH of LA to GVL, we used different hydrogen donor (2-PrOH, deuterated 2-PrOH-d 8 and excess tert-butanol) to study the mechanism and the rate-determining step. After the reaction, the products were measured by GC-MS (Thermo TRACE 1300ISQ) and 1H NMR (Bruker AVANCE III). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts The composition, structure, physicochemical and morphology of catalysts in this study were characterized via several chemical-physical techniques. SEM and TEM images showed that Zr-LigS are composed of irregular nanoparticles, which ranged from 120 nm to 200 nm ( Fig. 1A-F). TEM image showed the irregular Zr nanoparticles size was range from 2 to 7 nm (Fig. 3D-E). In the HRTEM image of Zr-LigS, three typical lattice spacing of 0.163 nm, 0.184 nm and 0.231 nm was attributed to (212), (220) and (120) of the ZrO2, respectively, suggesting the presence of ZrO2 particle in the Zr-LigS catalyst. The elemental mappings from high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HADDF-STEM) in Fig. 1G-K showed the distribution of C, O, S and Zr on the Zr-LigS material. The FTIR spectra were performed to investigate the modification of Zr species on LigS ( Fig. 2 A). A strong band at 1609 cm−1 and 1458 cm−1 corresponding to aromatic ring double-bond stretching (CC) and symmetric phenolic hydroxyl group were observed in both LigS and Zr-LigS. Besides, both LigS and Zr-LigS showed the enhanced band at 1117 cm−1 and 1038 cm−1 assigned to antisymmetric and symmetric SO2 stretching mode, respectively. Meanwhile, broad bands at 655 cm−1 and 520 cm−1 were attributed to the C–S bond in both LigS and Zr-LigS.( Table 1) [49,50]. In contrast, vibrational band at 1512 cm−1 attributed to the antisymmetric phenolic hydroxyl group in LigS was shifted to 1522 cm−1 in Zr-LigS, suggesting the phenolic hydroxyl groups (Ar-OH) of LigS was coordinated with Zr4+ species. The N2 adsorption and desorption isotherm of Zr-LigS showed a typical type IV isotherms with hysteresis loops in Fig. S1, suggesting the presence of porous structure in Zr-LigS catalyst [45]. Surface area and pore volume of LigS and Zr-LigS were shown in Table S1, LigS had low surface area and pore volume. In contrast, Zr-LigS had a much higher surface area (105.7 m2 g−1), pore volume (0.141 cm3g−1) and pore diameter (5.3 nm). The diffusion of reactants and accessibility of active sites were enhanced by the coordination of Zr and LigS. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was carried to study the thermal stability of Zr-LigS and LigS at the reaction temperatures (Fig. 2B, C). The weight of LigS had a slight loss below 104.5 °C, which may be attributed to the desorption of water. There was a steep curve from 104.5 °C to 350 °C, suggesting the weight loss was faster in this stage, which is attributed to the pyrolysis of oxygen group on LigS. The weight loss decreased after loading the metal Zr to LigS, which is attributed to the Zr species. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) results were shown in Fig. 2D, it showed that ZrO2 was crystalline with a monoclinic structure. In contrast, XRD pattern of Zr-LigS showed only obvious broad peak without obvious crystalline, indicating irregular connectivity between Zr4+ species and LigS and the Zr-LigS catalysts were amorphous structure, which is different from ZrO2, which has high crystallinity with monoclinic structure. It is worth noting that the XRD pattern showed that no ZrO2 nanoparticle was observed, which was exhibited in the HRTEM, this could be explained by the small size of the ZrO2 crystallites (2–7 nm) and low amount of ZrO2 species. The chemical state of ZrO2, Zr-LigS and LigS catalysts were characterized by X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). In the XPS spectra of Zr-LigS and ZrO2 (Fig. 2E), strong peaks at 182.01 eV and 184.35 eV, assigned to Zr 3d 5/2 and 3d 3/2(ZrO2), were shift to 182.58 eV and 184.98 eV (Zr-LigS). The peak shift suggested that there is higher positive charge on Zr in Zr-LigS and therefore stronger Lewis acid sites were conducted in Zr-LigS [54]. Besides, the binding energy of O 1 s in Zr-LigS is attributed to the interaction of metal Zr and LigS, which is higher than the interaction of Zr and O in ZrO2 and lower than the interaction of -Ar-OH in raw LigS (Fig. 2F). The O 1 s binding energy in Zr-LigS is attributed to negative charge on O atom, which declared a medium base strength of Zr-LigS. The XPS results suggest that O atom in LigS is the basic site to balance the Lewis acidic sites Zr4+, which will form the -Ar-O-Zr-O-Ar- frameworks. The acid-base properties of M-LigS (Zr, Al, Zn, Fe, Hf and Cu) and ZrO2 were characterized by CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD. Generally, the desorption of CO2 and NH3 reflected the strength and density of acid-base properties of catalysts. Zr-LigS has a longer desorption time and higher desorption temperature of CO2 and NH3 than ZrO2, suggesting Zr-LigS has more acidic-basic site compared with ZrO2 (Fig. 2G, H). The density of acidic-basic sites were shown in Table S2. Among these M-LigS catalyst, Hf-LigS and Zn-LigS showed highest acidic sites (4.412 mol/g) and basic sites (11.715 mol/g), respectively. Zr-LigS showed moderate acid-base properties (Acid/base~1). During the hydrothermal of LigS and Zr4+, the -Ar-O-Zr-O-Ar- frameworks were formed by the coordination of Zr4+ and -Ar-O, which were attributed to Zr4+ acidic sites and O2- basic sites. To further explore the Lewis acidic sites and BAS of Zr-LigS catalysts, transmission FTIR spectra of pyridine adsorption at three different temperatures (150 °C, 225 °C and 275 °C). As is shown in Fig. 1I, the adsorption of pyridine on Zr-LigS spectra showed Lewis acid bands at 1445 cm−1 and 1606 cm−1, Brønsted acid band at 1540 cm−1 and both Lewis and Brønsted acid band at 1490 cm−1. The hydrolysis of H2O and acidic ZrCl4 could form Zr(OH)4 and HCl, resulting in the ion exchange of Na+ and H+, which promoted the formation of Brønsted acid (-SO3H) in Zr-LigS. 3.2 Hydrogenation of Levulinic acid (LA) over various catalysts The catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of LA with 2-propanol (IPA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) was employed to evaluate the performance of various catalysts and the results were shown in Table 1. A blank run showed the CTH of LA to GVL did not proceed in the presence of catalyst at 150 °C for 6 h ( Table 2, Entry 1). The LigS precursor also gave scarcely conversion of LA, suggesting the acidic LigS was not active in the CTH reaction (Table 2, Entry 2). Commercial ZrO2 only gave low activity with 15.8% LA conversion and 3.5% GVL yield (Table 2, Entry 3). Besides, only 17.8% LA conversion and 4.8% GVL selectivity were obtained when the mixture of blank ZrO2 and sodium ligninsulfonate was used as catalyst, indicating the physical mixing of Zr and sodium ligninsulfonate is not able to catalyze the CTH reaction (Table 2, Entry 4). The other Zr-containing commercial chemicals (ZrCl4 and ZrOCl2) have strong Lewis acid sites, which also showed low LA conversion and GVL yield under the investigated conditions (Table 2, Entry 5–6). When the M-lignosulfonate catalysts were used for the hydrogenation of LA (Table 2, Entry 7–16), better catalytic performance were obtained and the Zr-LigS exhibited the highest LA conversion (61.8%), GVL yield (59.2%) and TOF (1.63 h−1), the excellent catalytic performance over Zr-LigS catalyst may be attributed to the moderate acid-base property (acid/base ~1) (Table S2). When the reaction time was further increased to 12 h, a near quantitative LA conversion (94.8%) and GVL yield (92.5%) were obtained. Besides, the effect of initial Zr metal to lignosulfonate ratio ranged from 0.5 to 2 were studied. The conversion of LA was remarkably increased from 42.8% to 61.8% with the Zr/lignosulfonate mass ratio increased from 0.5 to 1 (Table 2, Entry 12–13). However, further increasing the Zr-containing in Zr-LigS catalyst has slightly enhanced the LA conversion. The slight improvement in LA conversion may be attributed to the constant phenolic hydroxyl in lignosulfonate, which would coordinate with fixed amount of Zr. Furthermore, the conventional metal organic framework UIO-66 is reported as an excellent acid catalyst, which only show a low LA conversion (23.5%) in the CTH of LA (Table 2, Entry 17). With the combination of CTH reactions and the characterization of catalysts, we assumed that the appropriate density and strength of acidic and basic sites are the crucial role for the CTH of LA to GVL. The mechanism by which acidic-basic sites affects activity will be elucidated via in-situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy and poisoning experiments in the following section. 3.3 Identifying the active sites for CTH of LA In order to explore the role of acid-base properties in the CTH of LA reaction, benzoic acid, pyridine and 2,6-lutidine were employed as poisoning additive to the CTH reaction. When benzoic acid was introduced to the reaction system, a drastic drop in LA conversion and GVL yield was obtained, suggesting that the basic sites in Zr-LigS catalyst played a vital role in the CTH of LA ( Table 3, Entry 2). However, the LA conversion increased as the addition of pyridine, a poisoning additive to acidic sites, suggesting the CTH reaction was suppressed by the acidic sites. To identify the role of acidic sites (Lewis and Brønsted acid) on the CTH reaction, the BAS were selectively poisoned by the additive 2,6-lutidine, a conspicuous increase in LA conversion and GVL yield, suggesting BAS are the barrier for the CTH reaction. The poison experiments suggested that the basic sites played a crucial role in the CTH reaction. In our previous study, we elucidated that organic acid molecules with gas-phase deprotonation enthalpy (GPDE) below ~1625 kJ/mol can in-situ generate BAS and corresponding salts on the catalyst surface in gas phase [55]. However, the presence of solvents, i.e., IPA in this study poses great challenge in exploring structure-activity relationships because most of the characterizations were carried under vacuum or vapor phase. Thus, in-situ ATR-FTIR was employed to study the mechanism of CTH reaction (Fig. 3A). In-situ ATR-FTIR results show that LA suppress the CTH reaction by generating in-situ BAS that are capable of catalyzing side reactions. Upon introduction of LA to Zr-LigS in IPA solutions, we observed the following characteristic bands: 1702 cm−1, the carbonyl stretching mode of molecularly adsorbed LA; bands at 1440 cm−1, 1405 cm−1 and 1370 cm−1, assigned to CH3 and OH bending mode of adsorbed LA; 1554 cm−1, attributed to the [O-C-O]-, stretching mode of sodium levulinate, which formed from the dissociative adsorption of Zr-LigS ( Fig. 3B and Table 1). In our previous work, the dissociative adsorption of organic acid on catalyst with Lewis acidic sites would generate a corresponding sodium salt species and a BAS[63]. Therefore, in-situ generated BAS on Zr-LigS may be an obstacle in the CTH reaction. Upon subsequent adsorption of pyridine on the Zr-LigS catalyst, all bands associated with LA disappear with new bands appear at 1445 cm−1 and 1593 cm−1 attributed to Lewis acid, 1545 cm−1 attributed to Brønsted acid and 1490 cm−1 attributed to Brønsted and Lewis acid, suggesting BAS and sodium levulinate generated from the dissociative adsorption of LA were quenched by the adsorption of pyridine. To further confirm the speculation and gain more insight to the role of in-situ BAS on the CTH reaction, LA and its esters (methyl levulinate and Ethyl levulinate) were employed in the CTH reaction. As is shown in Table 3, higher reactant conversion and GVL yield were obtained when the LAs esters were employed at the investigation conditions. There were mainly two reasons accounting for the higher conversion of LAs ester than LA: (1) the presence of ester group is the barrier for the dissociative adsorption and generated in-situ BAS which would facilitate the CTH reaction. (2) the LAs ester is the intermediate in the CTH of LA and alcohols. 3.4 Solvents effect The solvents are the hydrogen donor in the CTH of LA, and the solvent effect was study with various alcohols. As depicted in Table 4, both primary and secondary alcohols are capable to donate hydrogen for the CTH of LA while tert-butanol is unable to provide hydrogen, suggesting the β-H in alcohol is indispensable for the CTH reaction. Besides, the secondary alcohol (IPA, 4-butanol and 3-pentanol) gave better LA conversion and GVL yield than the primary alcohol (methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol and 1-butanol). It is reported that the secondary alcohols had lower reduction potential than primary alcohol. Furthermore, IPA showed a higher LA conversion compared with the long-chain alcohols (4-butanol and 3-pentanol), which may be attributed to more significant negative steric effect in long chain alcohols, which will suppress the diffusion of the reactant into the channel of Zr-LigS catalyst. Therefore, IPA was the best solvent and therefore IPA was employed in the next experiments. 3.5 Kinetic study In order to further understand the relationship between active sites of Zr-LigS and the performance of catalyst, kinetic experiments were carried. As shown in Fig. 3C, the reaction temperature played a significant role in the catalytic performance of Zr-LigS for the CTH of LA from 80 °C to 250 °C. When the reaction was conducted at 80 °C, only 1.3% LA was converted to GVL, suggesting CTH reaction is hard to proceed at low temperature. Upon increasing temperature to 160 °C, LA conversion dramatically increased to 85.7% with a high GVL selectivity. However, the GVL selectivity gradually declined with a further increased temperature. The main side reactions are included in Scheme 1: the formation of LA-LA condensation products via the self-condensation of LA; ring cleavage and further hydrogen products 1,4-pentanediol; ring cleavage to pentenoic acid and further etherification with IPA. Among those side products, both 1,4-pentanediol, levulinic esters and valerate esters are high quality biofuels and additives. Therefore, a suitable temperature was 150 °C for the preparing GVL with high selectivity. 3.7 Reaction pathway The time course of CTH reaction over Zr-LigS catalyst was conducted at 150 °C to study the reaction pathway. The distribution of products in the reaction process of CTH of LA are shown in Fig. 3D. The domain products are target chemical GVL and isopropyl levulinate (IPLA, esterification of LA and IPA). The byproduct isopropyl levulinate decreased after 3 h with GVL increased, indicating IPLA was converted faster than they are formed. It may be converted to GVL in two pathways: (1) IPLA can be reversibly converted to LA and isopropanol, and finally transferred to GVL by CTH reaction; (2) IPLA is intermediate and then it could be converted to GVL directly. The esterification of LA and isopropanol may be attributed to the in-situ BAS which generated from the dissociative adsorption of LA. The esterification is also of importance in the upgradation of biomass-derived chemical to fuel additive and high value products. 3.8 Recycling experiments The catalyst reusability is of great importance in determining the potential value in the industry application. The recycling experiments of Zr-LigS for the CTH of LA were conducted by maintaining approximately 60% LA conversion at 150 °C for 6 h (Fig. 3E). After the first cycle, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation and then washed with IPA 3 times and dried at 60 °C overnight. Due to the loss of catalyst, a small scale of CTH experiment was conducted to keep the same substrate, solvent and catalyst ratio. The LA conversion decreased from 61.8% to 57.4% and the selectivity decrease from 95.8% to 89.7% after six runs, exhibiting the reusability of catalyst. When the reaction time was further increased to 12 h, the LA conversion and GVL selectivity were increased to 94.8% and 97.6%, respectively. The used catalyst was characterized by XRD and ICP. The XRD pattern suggested that the amorphous morphology of Zr-LigS remained the same as fresh catalyst. Furthermore, the IPC results showed small amount of Zr and S were leaching after six cycle of reactions. The slightly decrease in the LA conversion may due to the loss of the small amount of acidic-basic site (Zr and S). 3.9 Reaction mechanism study There are two possible mechanisms for the hydrogenation of LA to GVL, and the main difference between those two hydrogenation mechanisms is whether the adsorption of the H being transferred onto the surface of catalyst (Fig.S3). The formation of six-membered ring configuration and then the β-H of alcohol is transferred to the ketone carbon atom of LA in the Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley (MPV) mechanism (Fig. S3A) [56]. The H being transferred was adsorbed onto the catalyst surface because the H transfer was occurred in a converted step [56,57]. Therefore, the β-H of IPA would be directly transferred to the ketone carbon atom in LA when 2-propanol-d 8 was employed as hydrogen donor. In contrast, the metal mediated hydrogenation pathway included two consecutive steps (Fig. 3B): firstly, the dehydration of 2-propanol (IPA) on meal active sites to form acetone and adsorbed H atoms. Then the adsorbed H atom was transferred to ketone of LA. In the metal dihydride pathway, all of the H atoms are firstly adsorbed on metal active site prior to the addition to ketone of LA. However, using 2-propanol-d 8 to replace 2-propanol-d 0 can not differentiate the two mechanisms because the formed GVL had identical isotopic structure by either mechanism. Therefore, isotopic labeling experiments in 2-propanol-d 0 and deuterated 2-propanol-d 8 with excess tert-butanol were conducted to reveal the CTH reaction mechanism over the Zr-LigS catalyst. Because of the in excess tert-butanol, most of the O-H bond in excess tert-butanol will exchange with O-D in 2-propanol-d 8 due to the fast O-H/O-D exchange between the alcohols. Therefore, 2-propanol-d 7 (CD3CD(OH)CD3) is the majority of the D (or H) donor when the mixture solution (2-propanol-d 8 and in excess tert-butanol) is used. The GC-MS fragmentation pattern of GVL generated with 2-propanol-d 0 as hydrogen donor matched well with the NIST database (Fig. S8). The most intense peak was the parent ion of GVL (100 amu) in the blue bar (Fig. 3b). A clear 1 amu mass shift was shown in Fig. 3b (purple bar) when 2-propanol -d 8 with excess tert-butanol was used under the same reaction conditions, suggesting the concerted intermolecular hydride transfer mechanism is the main reaction pathway in the hydrogenation of LA into GVL. Combined with physicochemical characterization, performance of catalysts, poisoning experiment, in-situ ATR-FTIR, kinetic study and isotopic labeling experiments, we proposed the mechanism for the CTH of LA over Zr-LigS catalyst in Scheme 2. Firstly, the dissociative adsorption IPA and LA on Zr-LigS to form the corresponding alkoxide and hydrogen and deprotonated LA, respectively. Meanwhile, the ketone group in the adsorbed LA was activated to form the six-membered ring transition state with alcohols, resulting in the H transferred to ketone group by β-H elimination and producing the GVL and acetone. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, an efficient Zr-ligS catalyst for the CTH of LA to GVL was prepared by a simple and nontoxic hydrothermal method. The resulting Zr-LigS exhibited excellent catalytic activity in 92.5% GVL yield under mild conditions. It was found that the strong interaction between Zr species and LigS led to the formation of strong basic sites in the catalyst. Mechanism studies revealed that the basic sites contributed to the excellent catalytic performance in the CTH reaction while in-situ generated BAS on Zr-LigS are an obstacle. Kinetic experiments demonstrated the activation energy of the CTH of LA over Zr-LigS was as low as 41.9 kJ/mol. Isotopic labeling experiments suggested the β-H in isopropanol was direct transfer to the CO bond of adsorbed LA via the six-membered intermediates. coredata.dc:description: Production of γ-valerolactone (GVL) from biomass-derived platform levulinic acid (LA) via catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) over renewable lignosulfonate-derived catalyst is reported herein. Lignosulfonate-derived catalysts were prepared by assembled Zr-metals with sodium lignosulfonate (LigS) derived from the industry paper waste. The resulting Zr-LigS catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance in 92.5% GVL yield under mild conditions. With the combination of detail catalyst characterizations, catalytic performance of the Zr-LigS catalyst, in-situ ATR-FTIR and poisoning experiments, the hydrothermal treatment of Zr4+ and LigS resulted in the formation of basic sites, which contributed significantly to the CTH reaction. Kinetic experiments demonstrated that the activation energy was as low as 41.9 kJ/mol. Furthermore, isotopic labeling experiments suggested that the β-H in isopropanol is transferred to the CO bond of LA by the formation of six-membered intermediates on the basic sites, which is the rate-determining step.
coredata.dc:title: Sustainable metal-lignosulfonate catalyst for efficient catalytic transfer hydrogenation of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone
